title: Dean Foods to Remain Standalone Business After Strategic Review
text:
Dean’s operations have been pressured by U.S. consumers moving away from milk.

Dean Foods Co. DF 9.52% , which had been considering strategic alternatives including a sale, said Friday its board has decided the company will continue operating independently.

The food company’s board had been looking at strategic options since February. The company said Friday its board decided that operating under its newly named chief executive “will provide the best opportunity to enhance long-term shareholder value.”

The company’s operations have been pressured by U.S. consumers moving away from milk. The company also faces more competition from large retailers’ store-branded products. Last year, Deans’ sales fell 38% from a decade prior. The company, which is the biggest milk producer in the U.S., has been trying to cut expenses. Dean is also under the leadership of a relatively new chief executive, Eric Beringause, who started as CEO over a month ago. Dean’s previous CEO, Ralph Scozzafava, had been head of the company for about four years. Mr. Beringause underscored Dean’s cost-cutting attempts Friday, saying in prepared remarks that the company was “continuing to execute on our cost-savings and supply chain productivity programs.” Mr. Beringause has a history in the dairy and food industry—he was previously the CEO of Gehl Foods LLC, which makes food products and dairy-based drinks. Dean’s shares fell 1.7% in after-hours trading. Write to Allison Prang at allison.prang@wsj.com and Josh Beckerman at josh.beckerman@wsj.com
